column4: I just installed Breezy server, and after modifying the /etc/networking/interfaces file with my static IP address, everything went fine until...
I logged out, and the next morning, my Breezy server decided its static IP wasn't good enough, and it went out to a DHCP server and got a new IP
Is there another place I need to tell the server to stay with the Static IP I've been assigned?
a simple "/etc/init.d/networking restart" forced the server to read the config file again, and it went back to normal, but I want it to stay normal
/etc/networking/interfaces
sorry, it should be /etc/network/interfaces
/etc/network/interfaces is configured with "iface eth1 inet static" and my network details follow it.
yes, the 'static' means that it use static IP
when I restart the networking interfaces, it reads the file and remembers to be static again.
My problem is when I left work last night, I logged out, and it was still on a static IP.
When I got to work this morning, it had gotten a dynamic IP from a dhcp server.
is there an 'auto ethx' in it?
replace x with a number
Yes, "auto eth1" then the next line is the "iface eth1 inet static"
try to put the 'auto eth1' after the eth1 details
okay, I'll come back if it goes dhcp again.  (but since it happend during a 10 hour span, I'm not quite sure what triggered it.)
ok
do you know what the auto eth1 does?
Or is there a man page/document on /etc/network/interfaces ?
it's auto configuring the eth1 based on the config you provided in interfaces
man interfaces :)
Cool, thanks.
you're welcome
